titleStmt.title: Chilli Pepper Harran

Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

annotationBlock.spanGrp: Here in the city, let’s say we don’t buy red pepper powder for the house from the store or the market. We make it ourselves by hand. The red pepper from the market, we don’t eat it. We don’t eat it.

Because the red pepper from the market has bitterness, we don’t eat it. We make it ourselves by hand, so it becomes suitable and abundant at the same time. Every household makes 30 kilograms, 20 kilograms—not just by the kilogram, but we make a lot of it.
How do we make it? During the pepper season, when it’s time, every household brings 15 or 20 sacks home—yes, a lot—quite a lot.

We sort all of these, separating the large peppers and setting them aside. This is for making "pepper paste"—yes, pepper paste. We separate the large ones so there are no seeds left in them. The smaller ones still have seeds, and their seeds are plentiful, requiring a lot of effort to remove.

The larger peppers have fewer seeds. We continue separating the peppers, setting aside the ones we want to dry. This sorting process goes on until it's complete. Once we've finished sorting, we place the peppers on the rooftop, arranging them to face the sunlight like this.

w.n: *to spread or hang sth. to dry in the sun (vegetables++clothes)

annotationBlock.spanGrp: We position them toward the sun, meaning we spread them out under the sunlight. As for the peppers used for paste, we clean them separately. This is because if they still have seeds, it doesn’t... it doesn’t matter if they dry indoors.

Because no matter how much it dries, the seeds crumble and don’t remain inside—it falls out of them. As for the peppers used for paste, we clean them thoroughly and make sure there isn’t a single seed left. It’s more labor-intensive, meaning harder, to prepare the peppers used for making paste.

w.n: *to spread or hang sth. to dry in the sun (vegetables++clothes)

annotationBlock.spanGrp: We sort it carefully, removing all the seeds completely. Then we separate it and wash it. We bring the machine—the one used for grinding meat—and feed the peppers into it. Afterward, we add a little salt, spread it on trays, and place them under the sun.
Every day, we stir it under the sun until it dries completely. This is "ar-račāl" (the paste?). Once it’s ready, we take it and mix it with oil. We add oil, pepper, and salt.
We check again the amount of salt in this "ar-račāl" (paste), along with the tomato paste and red pepper. Then, we add oil, some salt, and pepper to it.
We mix it and place it in a jar. If the house is cold, there is no need to refrigerate it. If the weather is still cool, it won't spoil. It can stay good for the following year without spoiling.
For those who want and have the ability, they can place it in the refrigerator, so it doesn’t spoil. As for the dried peppers, after they dry, they remain a bit moist. We take nylon bags for it.
We fill the nylon bags and tightly seal the mouths of the bags, ensuring there is no air inside. Then, we place them directly under the sun, where they stay until the peppers are fully dried.

We turn the peppers inside the bags, and they remain in the bags until they turn black. It usually takes about a week or ten days for them to turn black. However, if it's summer and the weather is hot, it only takes two days for them to dry.

If the weather is like it is now, with cloudy skies, it might take a week or even longer for the peppers to turn dark. After spring comes, they become black, and then we remove them, dry them, and they are ready to be ground.

It means it goes in to be ground into a fine powder. We take it to the machines, for those who want that. In the past, we used to suffer with it, as we would grind it by hand, with our hands, until we were almost exhausted from the effort.
We would grind it by hand and put it into bags, tightly sealing the mouths of the bags. We used to use the large machine for grinding bulgur, which we would use in the past to grind it.

If you want, I can also tell you about the process of preparing bulgur. We would continue pounding it, one person sifting it through bran while another would pound it. We would end up sneezing so much that it felt like we were choking from the smell and smoke.

Thank God, these machines appeared and saved us from all that hard work. When I bring it, I just put it directly into the machine, and it comes out. We finish it right there, and that's how we prepare the red pepper at home.
